Patient Particulars: Name: JILL; Sex: Male; Education: Graduation
Presenting Complaints (Symptoms):
Presenting Complaint: Anxiety and fear
Chief Complaints:
1)Self criticism
2) Fear
3) Perfectionism
4) Comparison
Current Mental Status Examination: General appearance & behavior: Anxious; Speech: Normal, Mood & Affect: Anxious and sad; Thought: Negative, Perception: Normal, Cognitive functions: Distorted, Judgement: Poor
Psychotherapy Technique: Reflective listening, Thought Challenging and Cognitive restructuring..
Issues discussed in Current Session:
1) Problems: Patient has a strong desire to achieve more and has a tendency of perfection in their academic performance which leads to heightened anxiety and fear of failure.
2) Thinking Pattern: Patient has a belief that receiving the award validates his hard work which lead him to seek external validation, such as winning the awards which contributes to their anxiety and pressure to perform.
3) Self-image: He has a feeling of competition and inadequacy and feels threatened by the presence of someone they perceive as a competitor. This tendency leady to self-critical thoughts perfectionism which leads to anxiety.
4) Challenging Automatic Thoughts: The therapist encourages the client to challenge their automatic thoughts and cognitive distortions by examining the evidence and considering alternative perspectives. The goal is to promote more realistic and balanced thinking patterns.
5) Self-Compassion and Perspective: The client struggles to extend the same level of compassion and understanding to themselves that they would offer to others in similar situations. They need to develop a more compassionate and balanced perspective on their achievements and self-worth.
6) Action Plan: Therapist challenged his automatic thoughts and suggests using writing exercises, such as thought records, to identify and challenge their negative thought patterns. Also introduced self-compassion for a balanced perspective in life.
Action Plan: Writing exercises, such as thought records, to identify and challenge the negative thought patterns.
